Brawlhalla.Comment: As much as I want to give this game a negative review, I cannot justifiably do so. Most people who play this game will stay at a basic, casual level and never even notice or be forced to encounter the serious passivity problem this game has. So, despite my frustration with Brawlhalla, I am giving it a positive review. My recommendation would be to play with your friends and avoid taking this game too seriously. However, the prevalence of the passive float meta is noticeable as early as high platinum/low diamond, so be very forewarned and prepared to deal with it if you intend to play this game for many hours.

This game is unbelievably amazing if your sole purpose in life is to have a sweaty, fat 12-year-old plow their scythe up your anal cavity and rip out all vital organs. Brawhalla's vast range of unique combos and weapons exhibits such robust creativity to the extent that players only require two brain cells to be godly in this game! Furthermore, Brawhallaâs community is truly the pinnacle of gaming culture, where many players demonstrate good sportsmanship through a variety of fun emojis! And occasionally, players wish to further connect by inviting you to custom lobbies, to enact thoughtful exchanges with one another! I am starting to lose count of the amount of times I have been told to kill myself!! This gameâs only made me break two monitors! Only two!! If thatâs not considered a steal, then I donât know what is! Another positive aspect I feel is overlooked is its mysterious attributes. I will never know the degree of skill my opponent is going to have despite the claimed âaccuracyâ of ELO rating! Hell, I was at 1965 and plummeted back to gold! And I still got paired with Diamond Ranks! This obscure inconsistency adds a whole new excitement as I do not know what the â¥â¥â¥â¥ I am going to do to myself after a match! I am very appreciative of the experience Brawhalla has provided me, as it has excavated whole new emotions that I had yet to discover. To summarize, if youâre looking for that extra push to jump off that cliff or bridge, then this is the game for you!

This game used to be great, but declined started happening once megd hit the pro scene and players started copying his playstyle. now the game is even worst with passive/parry play. Where players will just use movement to bait out attacks and dash away when they miss like other side of the stage. Makes beautiful maps like demon island unplayable. its sad, because i picked this game up in 2020 and it used to be so much more aggressive and winning felt great. Now its just a headache to get through a match win or lose. I tried to smurf to see if things was different outside of diamond, but nope just as bad. I watched recent tourney and notice an insane increase of passive play in NA. Even the pros are worst with passive play, only Brazil and few hand full of pros are playing agro. On a stream sting ray was told he was an agro player.....That's were I said okay their is no return, but what put the icing on the cake was the hold dodge. By far the worst feature ever. Brawl with heavy string, cool highlights, smart agro, exciting plays to passive, reset neatural, two hits, drastically less strings, corner running, bait out with movement, and slowing the game down to the max. Brawl I want to say think you, you were by far the most consistent game I ever play. I truly enjoyed the good time. With that said good fcking luck brawl, game declining and these changes are killing the game. Also that dash change, made players way more passive. They can just dash away from your strings now/ dash to the other side while land. RIP Bmg/Brawl. Thank you for the memories

Honestly, this game used to be a love/hate relationship. It was an addiction for a long time, however the last 4 months. I've felt no desire to play this game anymore. I absolutely cannot stand the devs/ community. They don't care about this game nor their player base in any sort of way. They just release new skins every month to grab more of your money. I've spent a lot of money on this game and put a lot of my time into it. I'm finally quitting because no matter how many people speak up about the balance issues, things that need to be changed/ introduced. They do nothing and just release new skins. They nerf the wrong weapons, buff the weapons that were balanced. Change things that didn't need to be changed. The devs just rotate the meta around for each tournament to spice up the game play. There are so many things wrong about this game that could be improved/ fixed if they would just listen to their player-base. Like for example, the weapon throws/ reward for playing super passive ( and by passive, I don't mean playing smart and adapting to your opponents play style. I mean literally just running and waiting the entire game), etc. I know I'm not the only one that feels this way either. Would I have recommended this game in the past? Absolutely, it was different from other platform fighting games and a lot of fun. Would I recommend this game currently? no, I personally have gotten everything I wanted out of this game a long time ago and I only see it going down hill from here. It's just a big money grab. Maybe i'll revisit it in the future if things change. I doubt that will ever happen though. GG â¥â¥â¥â¥ game

Probably the best alternative to Super Smash Bros. out there right now and with it being smoother in terms of movement, more responsive and available for free on PC, the only real things smash has over it is diversity, familiar characters and complexity. The weapon system however isn't flawless and although I like the idea of a character having 2 optional weapons they all function the same besides three special moves that resemble smash attacks from smash bros, you have up/neutral, forward and downwards which is about the only differences between characters besides choice of weapon. Overall though, this game is a lot of fun to play and if you do need a smash alternative to play with friends out of either not wanting to emulate smash and play through netplay or just not owning a Wii U/3DS this game is definitely worth getting.

Brawlhalla isn't the only game in the genre that follows its formula, there are a few others. However, it has the added benefit over its competitors of being completely free to play. None of the various modes or features are locked behind a paywall, and the only use of money in the game is to purchase cosmetics such as skins and taunts. Therefore there is virtually no impediment for anyone to at least try the game out and see if it suits their tastes. Personally, I can't recommend it enough.

I will keep a watchful eye on Brawlhalla as development continues and it moves into open beta. More servers are added to expand the multiplayer. There are still many things that can be improved upon and hopefully those prices change a little bit. The little Smash player inside of me is optimistic, I hope he doesn't get knocked out of the board in one smash.

Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. This game is fun until you take it seriously and realise that there are deep rooted problems in the core of this game. Sure it may be fun playing with friends or for the first 200 ish hours, but after that you start to just get frusturated. I try to like this game, I really do, but the community is down right toxic and the game has some very unignorable problems that just make it not fun to spend a long period of time playing. One such problem is the float meta, you can be vastly surperior in skill to a player and still loose to them because the mechanics of this game promotes sitting back and waiting for your opponent to engage and then simply press the dodge button and punishing them, not a fun time. I have 420 hrs (nice) and can not recommend doing the same. If you're looking for a fun game with friends then go ahead and play it, but do not expect a fun time if you are looking for a new competitive platform fighter.

I have around 1000+ hours on the game and I would like to say that to really have fun in this game, you cant be a casual. You will be bonked all the time when you get started. Just bare with it and improve. Choose a character that you like and grind for a couple of weeks. The way to improve in this game is learning combos and then movement. By now after mastering those too you would probably be in plat. Now is when you really have fun. Learn to space and punish opponent's mishaps more effectively and once you are there you will really see why some people spend so much time in this game. Its a great game with a steep learning curve but after you deal with it, you will be having a great time. If you are into fighting games then this is a must have for you. Besides its FREEE!!!
Anyway, if you want a good arcade game to spend some time with and practice your manual skills, the choice is simple. Welcome to Brawlhalla!

3-matchmaking in ranked: this ties in with both of these but on a different level. The matchmaking system is based on ELO which is shown to you the moment you get into a lobby. the person you are going against is also shown this value and vise versa. In many cases the player that you are going against has a significantly higher or lower ELO than you do, at least in the hundresds of matches and hours i've put into this game thats what ive experienced. This leads to either you getting compleatly destroyed, whitch leads to the toxic behavior i mentioned earlier, or you stomping someone and them complaning about it in the same manner. I can't recomend this game to someone who wants to enjoy it by themselves because unless you are really good and really patient, you aren't going to have fun with it. However if you just want to play this game with friends and try some rediculous game modes and setting, go right for it. (I'd like to point out that i'm mid plat at the time of writing this review.)

Blue Mammoth's comitment to pushing the esports scene for this game is nothing short of admirable, and I have nothing but respect for the game's top players, but unless you're going for #1, there's nothing for you here. It's all polish and no depth. Attractive and fun, but ultimately hollow. After you've tossed 50+ hours into Brawlhalla and realize there's nothing there, go play Rivals of Aether, or better yet Melee, you can find everything you need to set it up on your PC short of a Melee .iso at blippi.gg. It's way more tough on newcomers but the return on investment and the satisfaction that comes on the road to improvement will be filled with self discovery and epiphanies about the assumptions you make when you're trying to beat an opponent. Heck, you'd probably even be better served by some *pedestrian* 2D fighter which actually has the tools necessary to play mindgames and strategize around player conditioning and mixups.

As someone who has played this game ever since 2016, I was able to see the changes the game went through. Upon initial release, it looked very promising especially for a time where smash was the only dominant fighting game. Playing the game, it was fun to have a combo based fighting game but also making combos balanced with the option to dodge. However, in the state it has been in, it's hard to ignore the issues the competitive scene may have. I'm sure if you are a brawlhalla player, you have probably complained about passive players at least once (even with not many hours). The dodge mechanic makes passive play awfully common and rewarding in this game; hardly even worth going in unless against significantly worse players. If you want a good visual of what I am talking about, literally watch ANY tournament not played by sandstorm or any other notoriously good players and the issue with dodge becomes more apparent. BMG has attempted to make dodge more balanced by increasing and reducing the cooldown on dodge dependent on if it's grounded, air, etc. But it still haunts this game. Don't get me wrong, there are definitely still ways to enjoy the competitive scene without playing passive but passive play is just sadly more rewarding in this game. Again, as for someone who has clocked nearly 800 hrs across multiple platforms, it's hard for me to recommend this to newer fighting game players and even a few veterans. I do truly hope this game fixes the issues with passive play but for now, I can not recommend this game in its current state.

as a party game to play with your friends? its fine. mediocre at best. as a competitive solo fighting game one-on-one? garbage. the game's mechanics themselves and numerous weapons actively reward you for sitting there waiting for enemies to approach you, then dodging and punishing them for whiffing. the entire meta of this game revolves around competitive footsies and passive playstyles. AKA the more you aggressive you play, the likelier you are to lose every other match. the only good game mode outside of ranked is experimental, since there are no casual 1v1s, and the entire ranked experience itself is absolutely abysmal. the community is beyond toxic, and its almost like BMG encourages it, because the report button is worthless. i cant go two matches without some idiot sitting on the other side of the stage or spamming sigs and typing "ez" in post-game chat after a 6 minute match of annoying, campy, overall braindead play. for the love of god and all that is holy, do not play this game if you want to have fun. go get yourself a real platform fighter, like the new Smash Bros. or maybe Rivals of Aether.

EDIT: Alright so Now that I've played the game a litle more I want to elaborate more. My word there are too many legends, this is taking ages. Point is, if they're in this game, I probably would. Anyway, fun game, when drunk at 2am. Any other time it is incredibly frustrating just getting â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ around by people who are for some reason in a rank considerably lower than where they should be, although I guess that comes with the territory when playing a game with a ranking system. The music for this game goes pretty hard, although that could be because I have game sound muted and always have Thomas Bergersen's Protectors of the Earth playing on repeat while playing this game. Actually, that could be exactly why the game soundtrack goes so hard, maybe I shouldn't have factored that into the review. Overall I would have to give this game a score of 4 out of 7, I would give it a lower score, however the disappointing gameplay is really redeemed by the absolutely banging soundtrack the game is put to. I mean, I don't know how much it cost to gets the rights to play Protectors of the Earth by Thomas Bergersen constantly without any other music but I have to say it was absolutely worth every penny spent and whoever made that decision deserves a significant pay raise. Maybe give them the money that was saved by not needing to purchase any other songs. It makes fumbling around trying to spam Orion side sigs seem like something straight out of a fantasy epic. I'm surprised more games don't take from his discography, the man composes good music. If the gameplay were on a par with the truly excellent soundtrack I wouldn't be able to resist giving Brawlhalla the coveted 5 out of 7 rating but alas, it is not. For this reason, I am unfortunately unable to list this game as one of my top 7 games on Steam, but it is fun though, would recommend (Protectors of the Earth goes hard).

Almost 750 hours on PC alone and with the release of the 4th battle pass season I've decided to rewrite my review on Brawlhalla. I think the game is good but the balance of the game has messed with the skill gap between players. At 400 hours I decided to actually reach platinum so I could say that I'm good enough at the game to actually give my opinion on it, I haven't touched competitive since and will refuse to for the foreseeable future because the community of the game is toxic and there's no longer any way to avoid it. I'm too good at the game to play with the friends I introduce without completely stomping them and ruining the fun, but I'm not good enough to casually stomp every match I play because I've stopped playing characters like Scarlet who can off screen with only a couple jump reads, or a scythe character who can light combo to oblivion because I don't see the fun in that anymore. I love the game and I'm too committed to quit, and I will not be recommending this game to anyone due to the toxic community and blurry balance of the game. Brawlhalla is a game I'm cursed to care about and keep returning to like Destiny.

Itâs tempting to view Nintendoâs Super Smash Bros. franchise as one of a kind. But recently, other games have attempted to capture that same accessible blend of platforming and fighting. If you enjoy Smash Bros. gameplay, but for some reason dislike Nintendo characters, you have options. Originally released in 2017, following a beta in 2015, Brawlhalla remains the alternative platform fighter with perhaps the most staying power. The free-to-play game sports a unique and approachable, if unpolished, set of fighting mechanics that appeals to even veteran Smash fans. Nintendo Switch owners should still stick to Super Smash Bros. Ultimate, as that game doesnât lock the bulk of its content behind paywalls. However, as a crossplay-friendly console, mobile, and PC game, Brawlhalla is the platform fighter for the rest of us.

I enjoyed the game for a bit, but it has glaring issues. The game is similar to super smash brothers where you select a character and beat up your opponents in multiple different game modes. Its fun casually. But to do well in online ranked modes you better have good internet connection or something. From my experience, some of my attacks "hit" my opponent (I get an audio cue telling me my attack hit), but they continue as if they weren't hit. Sometimes my attacks hit, and my opponent suffers only reduced knockback. Sometimes my opponents are able to execute an incredible number of actions right before my eyes, yet when I input a string of commands, there is just insane lag, like my character is moving through thick syrup lol. There are stats on characters that affect move speed and combat speed, but this is just something else.

There must be a counter to this obvious inbalance? Yes there is, it comes in the form of throwing your weapon. Throwing your weapon will hitstun the opponent and allow you to re-equip and attack the opponent within the same frame. Due to the fact that there is no priority, deflection or parry systems in this game it ends up devolving into who can throw their weapon the most. An excellent read followed up by a perfectively timed smash is all made pointless when the enemy throws their weapon at you at the last second with no punishment available for such an audacious and should-be-punishable move. I could go on forever about the games combat flaws but honestly for a free to play game it is good fun but very shallow. I don't recommend taking this game seriously as a competitive fighter as you will disappointed with the shallow button mashing, weapon throwing facade it turns into at high levels of play.

So, I started playing brawlhalla in late 2017. Initially I thought it was one of those games you come in to play with friends from time to time, but as soon as I started playing it I realized that I would love this game. I used to play with my friends in private games and it was a lot of fun, then slowly I went to try ranked, surely if you just started playing, you will find people who will tell you that you are a spammer and that you use a lot of "special attacks" as initially many people say... that's what made me keep playing it, the desire to outdo my ranked friends and reach the pro players who played this game, fascinated me how they could know so many mechanics in this game and it made me want to reach the highest peak or receive the rank diamond and finally I did it. After a lot of effort in this game and a lot of playing I think this has been the best time to leave a comment / opinion about this game. There have been a lot of times when the game made me ragequit, but after all I like a lot as a game. I strongly recommend this free game.

Play one of 14 different characters, each with unique weapons and abilities to use in either Solo-tournament play against NPC Characters, or Online PVP, Custom Online play, or Ranked 1v1 battle. The stage I played in the solo-play tournament, was a king of the hill style 3 on 1 match. Myself and 3 NPC players each used combo moves and various weapons that dropped from the sky to knock each other off the plateau. The characters are cartoonish, but kinda cute and the play-style is simplistic but actually a lot of fun. I normally don't like PVP games, but this one was fun to play. Now it is still in the Beta stage, so it is subject to change, but Brawlhalla would be fun to play with friends as it currently stands.

Brawlhalla. People who haven't played this game but have seen it will often tell you that its a super smash bros rip off, and well they're not far off aye. It is a very addicting little fighting game that will run on almost any machine and is completely free. Its dynamics set it apart from other fighting games. its simplistic style on the surface is sure to make you think that it is simple, but make no mistake.  this game takes hundreds of hours just to get a basic understanding of all weapons, and hundreds more to master. IF you like in depth technical fighting games, you'll like this. if you like casual fun fighting game play you will like this. Its hard not to like Brawlhalla. Be warned. If you start playing this game it might be hard to stop. Your choice.... good luck.

In 2021 you would think one of the biggest fighting games on Steam would at the very least have decent optimization as people have 4k monitors. Nope, no chance, not Brawlhalla. It's honestly astonishing how a game that's been around since 2017 with a dev team that's backed by Ubisoft has such piss poor optimization. In the game there's no way to change your screen resolution or graphics settings, all you can do is change it from Full Screen to either Maximized or Windowed. Unfortunately, that can cause input delays and that's horrible for any online fighter. I know it's a long shot, but maybe by 2031 Brawlhalla will finally have optimization that even old indie titles with single developers have in their games.

Another huge problem is the community. Higher ranked people are nice and will actually try to help you, but in ranks like gold and silver, almost everyone is a jerk. When you lose, they'll brag and spam a phrase to make fun of you, even if they only beat you by a little. If you win, they'll call you out for spamming or just complain and say you got lucky. It makes for an overall toxic community with players staring out. Brawlhalla is a free game though, so perhaps I should not harshly criticize it. It can be fun for a few hours at most, but the core concepts of the game make for bland, repetitive and clunky gameplay, and the community will just make you mad.

Thereâs just so much here, and Iâve rarely seen a game with so many enjoyable and replayable ideas in a single package. Brawlhalla is a fighting game heavily based on Super Smash Bros: you control a character and you have to beat up to other 3 players, hitting an enemy will make their damage go higher: the higher the damage the further they'll get knocked back with strong attacks, get pushed off the stage and you lose. However the main differences between this game and Smash Bros are the much more fast paced gameplay, the presence of full working weapons (picking a glowing sword will give your character one of the 2 random weapons they can use, each one will completely change and improve your moves) with incredibly different effects, nice stages (all pretty harmless with the exception of a few moving platforms here and there, making each battle a lot more skill-based compared to Smash's hazardous stages), funny extra gamemodes (like one the resembles American Football where you have to bring a ball to the opponent's goal and another one where you are given an endless amount of snowballs as the only attack, actually turning the battle in an hilarious snowball fight) and amazing graphics and sountrack all make Brawlhalla a must-have for any fan of Super Smash Bros or fighting games in general.

the servers are absolutely terrible for a game that requires split second inputs. they fluctuate from bad, horrible, reasonable, and every once in a blue moon, fast. but the fast times are fleeting and rare and it makes you want to pull your hair out. nomatter what you do you will never be able to fix the issue. whether you buy a faster computer, internet, peripherals. and for some reason, their ranked set up causes lag in order to "balance", which just ends up gimping both parties. the only way this game is fairly competitive is if you happen to be lucky and live in a place where the connection is fluid. but ive lived in 4 different places and i havent found it. if i were you i would avoid this game like the plague unless you want to spend alot of money to fix an unfixable problem in order to chase an opportunity to actually be rewarded for your talent. im plat 5 because i hit a streak of good internet ONE DAY. but mostly i get pushed back down to low plat, and even sometimes high gold. save yourself the headache. the game would be brilliant if it actually did what it was supposed to.

Brawlhalla still stands as a solid example of how to do a proper platform fighter, with several game modes, a diverse cast and a beautiful art style making this one easy to recommend. Perhaps best of all, itâs totally free, so you really donât have anything to lose by giving it a try. At worst, youâll find a Smash clone that doesnât have a ton of new ideas; at best, youâll find a new go-to for when you have a few friends over for a gaming session.

Brawlhalla is a fun, accessible platform fighter that has something for both casual players and those looking for competitive action. While its monetization model can be grindy, and some matchmaking issues may detract from the experience, the gameâs diverse roster, fluid gameplay, and frequent updates make it a strong contender in the genre. Whether you're playing casually with friends or climbing the ranked ladder, Brawlhalla offers plenty of value for players looking for an exciting, free-to-play brawler.

Great game, but was ruined by the devs, salty players, and updates in general. I started playing this game back in 2015, when it first went into open beta, and I used to play it a lot and really enjoyed it, but I pretty much just gave up on it when Ragnir (the dragon legend) came out. This game had a lot of potential and now it's rubbish. I've lost my patience with this game, to be honest. Every legend that came out after Ulgrim has either been broken, over-powered, or both (usually both). The game is very unbalanced at this point. New legends get all the attention while the old legends are neglected and most are completely outshined by the new ones. Most of the old legends, especially the classic ones (from Bodvar to Teros) have simple, extremely basic moves that can't even compare to the signatures of the new legends (e.g. usually just a simple swing of a weapon for old legend signatures). By contrast, newer legends (legends that came out after Ulgrim) have strong, fancy, detailed signatures/movesets that have a lot of range, are fast, and/or do a lot of damage, and so they're much stronger and are much easier to spam. Some of the newer legends even have unique abilities no other legend has, and while that isn't bad in and of itself, it ruins the balance of the game since older legends don't have unique abilities. And yet, the devs just seem to be neglecting older legends and don't revamp them, balance things out, or anything (and no, adjusting a single hitbox or boosting knockback by 1 does not count as "balancing," so don't try to say they aren't neglecting older legends). And we haven't even gotten to weapon balance (swords outclass most other weapons, spears are easy to spam, etc., and this has been a problem for a long time), older weapons versus newer weapons (gauntlets and now scythe, especially), the extremely toxic community (almost as toxic as Rumble Fighter's community), the intense lag (you can literally be attacking your opponent one moment and suiciding the next without knowing what's happening, among other things), etc. Overall, the game could've been so much fun and had a lot of potential, but the devs seem to have just screwed it up and haven't really listened to the community's complaints, mostly because the toxic players outnumber the other members of the community and are louder than they are, and that's because most of the other players have left BECAUSE of the toxic community, so it's just a cycle in that sense, where toxic players come, other players leave because of the toxic players, more toxic players come, and the cycle repeats. The game also isn't very friendly toward rookies. Most people that I knew that used to play this game during its earlier stages ("veteran players," if you will) seem to have just quit playing. I made it to Diamond (the highest rank) and I can't even say I'm proud of that accomplishment, since it really wasn't worth it. I could say more, but I think I've made my point. I can't recommend this game anymore. It's still free to play, but it's definitely no longer fun to play.

OK, first of all I have played this game for months and am Gold in both 1v1s and 2v2s. I have many hours in smash bros and a few in Rivals of Aether but I have always loved Brawlhalla. This game is appealing for its simplicity and fast paced gameplay. Observing reviews I've seen a lot of complaining about spamming and to that I say spamming is equaly prevalent in most other platform fighters.  My friends introduced me to this game as a way for my smash playing friends and I to play a game like this with friends that don't play smash. At first that is all it was, a smash substitute of sorts, but as I improved and learned the controls my relationship with this game evolved and I was grinding the game even when my friends weren't online to play with. The legends are all very well balanced partly because of the similar sized hurtboxes and similar speed, attack, and defense stats. Another reason I rarely get salty because "the other legend is just too OP against mine" is because each legend essentially has 2 built-in play styles in the form of their 2 weapons. This means that if you are struggling with one weapon, the other weapon might not have such a hard time. Coming from Smash Ultimate I was used to one-off approaches and far from true combos but this game allows for much faster paced gameplay and combos if you use the right characters. The devs truly love this game and give it regular updates as well as supporting the eSports scene greatly. For people who truly dislike this genre of game, this game might not change that, but to people who just haven't found a platform fighter that interests them I would say to try this game and get a few hours in.

Don't worry about money, as this game is one of the best out there for users who cant spend all of their money for free. Recommend to players who want a fighter game that is playable with friends. Amazing developers!

Brawlhalla is a fun action-based game where you get to choose your legend for each battle. There are many mechanics of the game that are easy to learn and once you master them you can quickly climb the ranks and gain Glory through Ranked 1v1. There are many different weapons in the game, and each legend has a unique combination of two different weapons.  There are also many fun game modes, such as FFA, Strikeout (where you choose 3 legends and you use a different legend for each of your lives), Friendly 2v2, Ranked 1v1, and Experimental 1v1. There are also weekly special brawl events, such as Kung Foot and Bubble Tag, but there are many more. Overall, Brawlhalla is very fun to play and it is enjoyable when you learn new skills.

Committing yourself to enjoying this game and learning how to play it, will always be the start to finding your passion for it. However you decide to play this game such as a joke, for fun, competitively, or just to battle your friends I know for a fact that you won't want to let go. Actually understanding this game sparks a desire to understand more about it, and to practice, learn, play, lose, win, flex, enjoy, share, and connect through this free-to-play fighting game developed as Brawlhalla. For a lot of people, this community and game becomes apart of their childhood, life, hobbies, Content, and even their job. For me the nostalgic feeling of Brawlhalla reminds me of when I first opened it on my first hour. interested and curious of how I could become something in Brawlhalla so then Brawlhalla could become something I feel is apart of me. From all the friendships I've created, to all the wholesome post-game conversations I've encountered. There's always a light side to look at when playing Brawl. I have played the game for almost a year now and currently have more then 2,000 hours on record. I've played while being open with a passion to be the better player I always know I can become. Interested in tournaments and Discord servers it becomes so easy to sink into Brawls welcoming community. With amazing content creators, friendly players, and very skilled professionals when you look in through the window you might finally realize you aren't outside, and in fact outside is through the door you could never find, until your spark of an interest let you find the way. The small and hidden aspects of Brawlhalla are what let it establish it's unknown qualities while being known for as a seemingly upfront free-to-play. The part of my life history that relates to brawlhalla will be remembered until I no longer have any memory at all. I seek for more in the depths of high tier game-play and communities as for now and the future. I'm not sure when I'll let go of a such a loving hobby and passion, and I'm not looking forward to. I truly hope others and more can experience Brawlhalla the way I did, with hope for prosperity and the scope for communion. People who read all of this will already have enough devotion to spark an interest in the game I've loved so dearly. Thank you.

However, like any game, Brawlhalla has its drawbacks. The matchmaking can sometimes be hit or miss, and you might encounter players of vastly different skill levels. Additionally, while the game is free, there are microtransactions for cosmetic items, which might not appeal to everyone. Despite these minor issues, Brawlhalla remains an excellent choice for a fun and competitive multiplayer experience. Whether you're a seasoned gamer or just looking for something to pass the time, Brawlhalla is a must-try.

The amount of time I've spent in this game would be surprising considering the score I'm giving it, but I cannot seriously recommend Brawlhalla when there are so many better ways to use your time. There's NO community in any online game I've faced (not even other F2P games such as LoL) that is as toxic as this one is. If you don't live close to one of the servers for this game your connection is jsut utter garbage. You're always gona have some sort of input lag. If you've ever played any fighting game you'll realize this game is very unbalanced and devs just cycle through metas to hype the tournaments up basically as they know exactly what they're doing and it's not balance. There's no penalty for doing or not doing stuff here (NO Rock Paper Scissors type of design you find in literally EVERY OTHER FIGHTING GAME). The whole economy behind this game revolves around being an â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥, taunts are the best selling in-app purchase by a mile. If you don't live in the US (or one of the 1st world countries) then good luck trying to buy anything as the premium in-game currency price isn't region adjusted. The more you play and the farther you get (up to Diamond) the more passive and boring the game becomes. There's footsies, there's defensive oriented characters in other fighting games but this is ridiculous... some matches will be stalemates where your opponent will literally just run away. As a matter of a fact, running away is objectively more effective than anythign else which is an incentive to play passively. Why? Because you have more options to run away, dodge, defend, throw your weapon, etc than you have to approach. Why would I recommend a game whose population is mostly kids yet it has the most toxic players ever? Everyone is tired ofthe toxicity, of the passiveness and the overall same-ness of the game. You don't have to believe me if you don't want to, few people really talk about this but it is the truth

As much as I have spent much time in this game. I can't recommend this game to anyone who wants to play a competitive platform fighter. The dodge mechanic makes it easy to escape combos and move around but it makes neutral a horrendous experience. Dodge is quick to recover and is basically a get out of jail freecard. Furthermore, the game has a lot of input lag so it isn't a crisp and fast feeling even with good internet. Lastly, community is toxic. This game has taunts and emotes to add further salt to injury. Playing ranked never felt good as everyone became so rude and protective of their elo. I recommend either Smash Melee or Rivals of Aether 1 or 2. Brawlhalla is only a fun game if you plan to play casually. No I am not a scrub, I was fairly good sitting between 2150-2200 diamond when I peaked so I ain't lying.

PVP is NOT forced and there is no drawback to avoiding it. It is in its own mode and its rewards are entirely cosmetic titles that appear on your graves when you die. When players die, at the location of their grave other players can summon an AI controlled copy ("Revenant") of that player and fight them for items similar to what they were wearing, as well as special currency and items required to summon assistance. Fighting Revenants often is great practice and loot.

Combat in this game is challenging, but it gives you the tools to survive it.  Between seven weapon types, three combat stances for each weapon, weapon and stance-specific skills, and two support skill trees  (magic and ninjutsu) there's a lot of depth and replayability to the game, while still being accessible in that, while there's a lot of complexity, you can complete the first playthrough with learning just the basics, and then hone your skills for optional side content and the new game plus modes.

But basically, this game gives you dozens of ways to customize your character. I'd say more so than Dark Souls does. But I'm not going to say it's better than Dark Souls. It's a different type of experience. Playing this won't scratch that Dark Souls itch you may have. But I think you'll have a lot of fun anyway.

due to that? Not once. If you can deal with a little difficulty in your games, this is my recommendation for you. Everything about this game sparkles, and it was probably my favorite thing to come out of 2017.

"Wow, that sounds pretty complicated. And you said this game was faster than Dark Souls as well?" Yes and yes. This game's combat is more complex, faster, combo-focused, and rewards aggressive play whereas Dark Souls is the opposite. Dark Souls is simple, slow, poke-focused, and rewards defensive play. But... that's what makes this game SO fun! This game is unashamedly about the combat whereas Dark Souls is more about the atmosphere and exploration. If you want to play a challenging, intricate, and stylish action game with fun combos then this is the game for you. I hope this clears up any confusion about whether Nioh is like Dark Souls. It's not. It is like a spiritual successor to Ninja Gaiden with Action RPG elements and... that's a good thing!

An easy recommend for veteran action game players and newcomers alike. Each early level and boss fights are designed to teach you subtly on skills you need to pass (learn to dodge and counter attack effectively, how to know when to be aggressive or putting on defence, realising how mobile you are and how to use it to your advantage, etc.), it might be hard but it is fair and rewarding. The length and depth of the game is worth the price; the gameplay action is fast, fluid, and visceral; the story and the setting of feudal Japan is interesting in its own rights.

It will smear you all over the mud, sweat, blood and tears unless you abuse magic and some other abilities, but it has some silver lining of complex and unique combat stance mechanics, with different weapons and their respective skills.
Overall Nioh is a good game with a few design decisions that I feel are really preventing it from being great. If you're a fan of souls-like games then you'll probably enjoy this, I certainly am.

Nioh scratches your Dark Souls itch perfectly. Level design is not as good as Dark Souls but combat is more complex and fun. If you are looking for playing the game in co-op mode, then remember that it will be unlocked after beating the first boss on the ship, after around 2 hours of gameplay and a lot of deaths obviously.

At the end of it all, Nioh becomes a game MUCH easier than Dark Souls in exploration, progression, and story comprehension, but MUCH harder in the actual combat mechanics. There's a breadth of skill trees for all weapon types, three different forms for how you use them that completely change their moveset, and expansive ninjitsu/magic systems. You HAVE to know your enemies in Nioh. You will not prevail until you do, almost instinctually. It cannot be brute forced, it must be comprehended. If you are willing to embark on that quest, you'll find a much more rewarding, much more satisfying experience than any other game in the genre. If you are not willing, I don't blame you. "Nioh is hard" is an understatement.

Nioh, to me, is a real work of art. So much customization, so much gameplay for the achievement hunter. It's pretty deep! I'm running out of text, but I said most of what I wanted in my rambling. You'll get used to it, and you can really overpower a lot of things when you learn how to use your skills, weapons, and other passives to full advantage. There is no right or wrong way to play Nioh. Almost any build can survive if they are strong enough. Armor and weapon levels are much more important than keeping your favorite old one. Always go for new stuff in each region and new game cycle when you can!  Trust me, you'll thank me later.  Amazing game 9/10 on my scale.

This game is NOT dark souls and is not meant to be compared to DS. What Koei Tecmo did was create an elaborate hardcore Action/RPG with elements of looting and progression through character customization. The setting takes place in medieval japan (i believe edo period) and you play as William. Nioh is an amazingly beautiful adventure crafted in a demonic alternate history of Japan while retaining some non-fiction elements such as certain characters and locations, the combat is easy-ish to learn and hard to master while upgrading your characters skills and abilities from a good size "skill tree" to chase that build and play style that not only you love but also to eventually be able to feel confident going into battle. For those that fear "ohhh this is a game where ill be OP and itll get boring" fret not because even at high levels and huge dmg output you can still get 1 hit by even the most simple enemies. If you're into japanese culture and love a good hardcore action RPG with looting and deep style progression then Nioh is for you, personally I absolutely LOVE Nioh and can't wait for the second installment! There is however one downside to the PC version though and that is this game is meant for a controller. At least IMO because on a controller it feels so much more natural and comfortable than having to figure out what all these wonky keybindings are, and yes you can play with a keyboard and mouse but for this game i just didn't find that right. Other than that i'd have to rate this game 10/10 for the literal thousands of hours you can put into it, solid gameplay mechanics, beautiful art style and graphics and a compelling (enough) story to follow.

A RPG for action junkies. Take the level structure of a soulslike (Fromsoft games still have better level design), the loot system of a typical Diablo-style ARPG and then incorporate a combat system with as much depth and variety as the best spectacle fighters. The combat is twitchy, fast and demands you time your attacks (Like Ninja Gaiden). Each weapon is useful and fun it's just a matter of mastering them. While definitely challenging (Sometimes cheap with an overabundance of ambushes) its satisfying to play. The story is hard to follow but when your gameplay is this good the story doesn't have to be anything special. The endgame can feel more grindy then you'd like and leveling up endgame gear is an odd process of recycling gear. These don't detract from this being an amazing RPG for us twitchy masochists (Team Ninja fans)
The music is great thou.

The game get compared a lot to dark souls, hence souls-like genre, but the game deserved its own place since you get rewarded for blocking more than i-framing through enemy attack. Granted its mission/level based game rather than interconnecting place, but the game offer a ton of replayability through its NG+ system. Upgrading equipment is pretty convoluted but when the game 'clicks' you'll get ton of enjoyment playing through. NG+++ (Way of the Wise) is required for platinum/all achievement run, finished mine on level 397/125 hrs in. Definitely recommend solid 8.5/10.

People call this a souls-like game, but it's inaccurate.  Nioh is a Ninja Gaiden x Diablo game with a bit of metroidvania (by today's standards).  The only souls resemblance is the "you die you loose your xp and have to retrieve it".  I loved this game, but hate when people mistake this for something it isn't then crap on it.  If you love an action RPG with a huge farm factory attached, this is the game for you.  Also, it's worth noting that this game fits any level of commitment.  At a certain level of play, the co-op can become difficult when you're tossed into missions that require Abyss gear and are at difficulties you haven't even touched.

Kusarigama are a little imba. Axe and Odachi feel a bit lacking in skills. Level design promotes paranoia. One does not simply "enter a room" in Nioh. You check all four corners, all four walls, you lure the enemies out and kill them one by one, then proceed to fall through a floor trap and die. Gear and stat system has a lot of depth but you're going to need to read the ultimate guide to figure out what Parry actually means and why it's lame. Lore is packed with Japanese mythology and historical figures like Oda Nobunaga and Afro Samurai. Clan war system is cool but whichever side has Date will always win. Join Sho anyways. The port quality is eerily similar to the Dark Souls 3 port quality so take that as you will. Overall an excellent game if you enjoy being angry, stressed, or scared all the time.

Easily one of the most underrated games I've ever played. because people expect challenge and get shocked when the game is actually difficult. You're never forced to farm or grind for anything, i reached NG++++ without ever having to farm or play the same level even twice, so i don't know what these people are complaining about nor do i understand complaints about enemies being too tanky, that means you don't know what their weaknesses are. try to utilize different elements for chaos debuff, aim for the weak spots etc. skill system gives you freedom for anything you want to try, weapons and gear are done in a way which allows you to experiment as much as you want. weapon variety is huge and each one has 3 different types of stances with their own separate skills that you can use to enjoy combat and find your personal playstyle, whether its playing patiently and waiting for a proper time to parry or to barrage enemies with powerful attacks. more skilled you are more satisfying Nioh becomes, so get good and have fun.
*What I would pay: Current retail price ($50) is definitely expensive so I would wait for a sale.

When all said and done this will go down as one of my favorite games of all time, and I'm honestly suprised I hadn't heard more about it before a co-worker told me about it.  If you are thinking about getting it, don't, just do it.

I will start off and say Nioh is not for everybody. Crushingly difficult and frustrating but immensely enjoyable, Nioh is definitely a game to get lost in. It's hard to describe Nioh without mentioning Dark Souls, but it isn't a ripoff, it's a great game with great combat system, more fast paced and intriguing story. The game's pacing is very well done and offers enough rewards to offset it's difficulty. The feeling of beating tough boss after multiple tries is intoxicating especially after you gain the rewards for all your troubles. It's fun to see genuine Japanese historical figures in a world of demons and spirits. It's definitely a lot to absorb at first but its never enough to make you feel overwhelmed by the experience.

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 12 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he let me borrow his controller. Me and my son then played in turns and I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.
If you are willing to overlook some of the more obvious flaws the game has, I would definitely recommend giving it a whirl especially when it is on a large discount.
Still, i would absolutly recommend it for the rock-solid combat.

I really wanted to like Nioh, but so far this is too much for me. It doesn't have the right risk/reward balance, and doesn't level the player's sense of achievement out as well with the sense of loss and failure inherent in a soulslike. It tends to be more on the infuriating side, with too many battles relying on one hit kills and environmental hazards to make them difficult. I would go so far as to say that this game is a health hazard for some people and should be used in caution, as it will tatter your nerves and disappoint you with it's downright and consistent unfairness and bitter taste left in your mouth when you do finally beat a boss...

The initial release was really shaky, but Koei has done a great job patching it up and fixing crashes and errors. They've also added mouse and keyboard support which was desperately needed. The game is great, tons of hours worth of brutal samurai action. Definitely worth the $50.00 USD.

That said, Nioh can bring quite a bit of fun. Some of the bosses are well-designed and give immense sense of accomplishment when defeated, some of the mechanics are really interesting and shed a new light on a well-known concept. And if you are a hoarder, Nioh has plenty of equipment for you to loot and upgrade. Nevertheless, as a whole, not recommended - the bad parts bring enough frustration to overshadow the good ones. Maybe Nioh 2 will fix some of them - although, judging from watching gameplay streams and videos, it didn't really.

And to players who complain about no native Mouse and Keyboard controls; Go play something else. You're playing the wrong games. I'd prefer you tell me you can't play the game with a guitar hero controller or rock band drum set, simply for the idea that you tried. Souls-like games have never been a mouse and keyboard thing to me, it doesn't feel natural to even hear someone say they play like that. Heathens.

All of this adds up to a unique and compelling experience, but perhaps not as memorable as a Dark Souls game. Either way I could easily recommend this game for anyone looking to dive into an easy-to-learn and hard-to-master Action RPG Souls-like, where you can practice with a great variety of weapon sets and gear to hone your mastery against aggressive enemies and many bosses, with a large economy of varied loot tables to keep you chasing for the elusive "perfect gear" should you choose to do so.

In the end, I recommend Nioh for fans of Action RPGs not just Souls fans. I'm turned off mainly by the levels instead of open world and I'm just not big on 1600s Japanese mythology.
Other than the missing weapons and armor the game is amazing and the detail is their that they took their time to make it the best it could be.
Still a good game if you're a fan of Ninja Gaiden.
The end game is very hard because even if you have the strongest gear you can still die in one shot. It's a great game and I recommend it if you're a souls-like challenger.

If you are any sort of fan of the 3d Ninja Gaidens of Team Ninja you owe it to yourself to get this game. Its ninja gaiden style action but with more rpg stuff, and more grounded and versatile combat. Imagine ninja gaiden with a stamina bar! It takes some getting used to but its so interesting and a great twist on an action rpg. Expect a bit of a learning curve, it took me about six hours just to beat the first area/boss, and get aquianted with the stances and managing stamina.

A truly fascinating souls style game. I would describe this as samurai dark souls, where the main character for some reason can use devil trigger. The unique combat of this game allows for builds that were not previously possible in souls games. That being said the second game in this series is a major improvement, I would recommend playing Nioh 2 first.
Besides that its a great game. The controls are pretty solid, the graphics are awesome and the skill tree is big enough to give some options to change builds.

A pretty decent souls-like experience full of challanges...and nonsense. The game goes pretty well until the sixth island (and the DLCs after that), when it becames disgustingly unbalanced. Most of the bosses one-shots you with more than half of their attacks, even if you're wearing top-notch medium armor with good toughness. And the missions get unfairly high difficulty rating towards the end, nowhere near your current character level, even if you beat all the side quests along the way. I played it all the way to the end (except the DLCs, which was just utter bulls***), it was alright, but it will never be a true souls-like game, because those are at least fair 'till the end. I still recommend it, because it deserves the attention.

Great Game. Loved it on PS4, but wanted it for the PC and finished it here. It's wonderfully optimized, which is surprising for Koei Temco. Loved their twist on histroical events and the amount of detail put into item descriptions for historical purposes. A good chunk of the game takes place during or around the Battle of Sekigahara which is my favorite time during the Sengoku Period. Most the respective officers during that time are there, but I had hoped to see Takatora Todo (You can choose his clan in the Clan Battles at least). The Amount of Armor and Weapon designs is truly apprciated, and each combat style between all the weapons for Low-Mid-High Stances. Bosses can be pretty difficult sometimes, multiplayer is fun, and the story is really interesting IMO. I can't wait for the second one!

Overall, Nioh is a challenging game where both your own skill and your equipments matter a lot. It does feel hard at first to get used to, and you have to learn more as you progress, but the wonderful combat system and setting are enough to keep me playing and improving.

Once I finally gave Nioh the time, it's unique artistic flair outshone what I found to be an occasionally repetitive and prohibitively difficult experience. As a long time FromSoft fan, I was drawn to Nioh back before it launched as a PlayStation exclusive. I participated in both the Alpha and Beta programs and became more excited at the prospect of a Sengoku-era Dark Souls with each passing hour of playtime I accrued. When it finally launched I decided to hold off until the time felt right, eventually not picking it up until much later for PC. While I can't say I enjoyed every hour I sunk into this title, by the end I felt its pros outweighed its cons. Give it a shot if it seems like your thing, just be prepared to consider anger management after the credits roll.

I love this game but I hate it on PC. I have tried every community fix as well as all fixes provided by Koei. I have even installed this on a PC with Intel/Nvidia hardware after believing it may be an AMD issue with no luck. The game becomes randomly unplayable with hard crashes and crashes to desktop that always include memory violation errors. I ended up well beyond the refund window simply because of cut scenes and believing an early 5 hour bug free stretch meant that I was okay. I ended up rebuying the game on PS4 and have loved it there. Do not buy this on PC, you have been warned.

Nioh is again a game that i love and hate its guts at the same time. In my opinion its by far the hardest soulslike game out there and i played many of them. Honestly its different enough that it can be considered its one thing. The combat is fun and the gameplay is addicting. Its loot system is like Diablo and Borderlands where you progress through the game and get more powerful purely from the gear that you collect rather than your levels. So be prepared for some grinding if you want to have an easier time. The problem with the game comes from the latr difficulties (NG+) While the first playthrough is piss easy IMHO the later difficulties get SO cheap and full of BS that the only way to progress is by insane grinding to get specific items and builds. In general getting one shotted or two shotted in this game is so common that you will scream â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ at every death. Not helping that the AI blatanly input reads your commands and reacts accordingly or that the DLCS have some hugely BS bosses with nanosecond attack strings. As a souls lover if you are trying out this game USE EVERY TOOL the game provides you and dont be afraid to cheese and use BS tactics to win cause the game does it too.

The combat is amazing. The way you can combo into different stances is really rewarding and most importantly, fun. However, this game reuses a lot of the same few enemies and the levels aren't that great. I usually found myself just rushing to the boss without much care for the level leading up to it, although finding shortcuts to the shrines were very satisfying. Be prepared to be running back to the boss over and over again because the bosses are unforgiving and kill you in 2-3 hits, so one mistake will cost you your life, but thankfully the bosses are very close to the shrines, especially if you have shortcuts leading to it unlocked.

I don't get the negative reviews. This is a totally awesome game. The fighting mechanics are unparalleled. Yes, it's soulslike without the lore or incredible level design; yes, it's overburdened with options to enhance, learn and modify stuff; yes, the story is borderline incomprehensible for a long time; yes, levels are recycled for side missions. But: The fighting mechanics are unparalleled! The system is easy to learn but complex at heart. It's neither button smashing nor ultra complex combos, it's mostly extremely precise timing aided by super responsive controls. You always know what you're doing - or should be doing. Each death is earned. After 120 hours I still can't stop playing although my game library screams for me to do other stuff. Nioh is great and if you like 3rd person fighting and own a controller (you MUST play with a controller) do yourself a favor and try this.

Other than that I do recommend the game if u buy on sale and you are fan of Soulslike games. It is easier than most of soulsgames, least that's how I felt but you'll still die quite a lot specially because some monster animations are weird, when you dodge sometimes the monster will spin around mid-animation and still hit you.

Despite what reviewers say(Polygon..KAPPA), this game doesn't actually have better combat than any souls game. You can become ridiculously overpowered almost immidiatly. You can become entirely invincible by saving your amrita items for when you need a spirit form crutch. Often times the boss mechanics border on the insane, and always lean more towards tedious than you'd like. If you're desperate for a souls susbstitute. Go for it. It's not bad, you'll just find yourself longing for the less linear and grind based action of any souls entry. If you're a fan of Bloodborne and find the other Souls series combat to slow, this game is fast paced enough to keep you engrossed.

I still have a very long journey ahead with this game, but if you were impressed by the unlimited ways of dying in a video game as in Dark Souls, definitely move over to Nioh. This game delivers that same 'make a small mistake pay for it with your life' mentality. Set in the era of Samurais and Ninjas, this game was built around my favorite time period of Japanese culture, albeit the demons destroying the world.

Have you ever thought about having a combination of Dark Souls and Diablo in the world of 17th century Japan? No? Well too bad, because Nioh is just that and it is amazing. Innovative customizable combat system, addictive gameplay, in a griddy, dark Japanese setting. The story is a bit weak in my opinion, but everything else compensates for that con.

This is a fantastic Souls-like game, with an incredibly fast and intricate combat system that leaves even Bloodborne in the dust. The challenge is immense, the gameplay is extremely satisfying, the bosses are challenging, and it's a great way to get that Souls-like fix for people tired of the original series. My only issues are that the balancing is kind of off, with enemies having way too much health and doing way too much damage half the time, and also that the game lacks in variety. There is no open world to explore. Many missions just reuse areas from previous ones, and it can get pretty grating going to the same place all the time. Enemies also are repeated very often. Almost too often. It gets tiring dealing with the same set of dudes over and over and over. However, when the game is fun, it is beyond worth playing. A great time, if a bit repetitive.

Once you finish the main story, it will give you a tip about how the highest rarity items work, which involves using the smith. If you have been ignoring forging, soul matching, and reforging up til now, now is the time to learn it!

Not as straight forward as Dark Souls 3 which was more about skill issue but not as painful as all these extra obstacles put in this game let alone the important aspect that changes your game play drastically, which is the camera and lock on feature when targeting. most of my hours are afk ngl. im about 15 hours in though and its popping, the stance system takes a college course education to understand, the enemies are all unpredictable and difficult, 1/3 attacks will one shot you and every boss will take at least an hour to master. that said, if you are willing to trek through the jank and outright â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ you will find yourself enjoying one of the most intuitive and unique combat systems ever designed. dont try to use every move at your disposal, youll just get overwhelmed. figure out what youre good at and maximize your skills. if youre more comfortable fighting enemies with precise attacks from a distance, use a spear. if youd rather be lightning fast and reactive, like i do, keep your armor weight low and grab a katana. there is much magic and ninjutsu to learn to buff your character and keep up ranged damage output, so grab whatever works best and put the enemy to work. everything has a weakness. if youre stuck on a boss dont try to grind it for hours, put on your best equipment and level your character before rushing at it again. this is one of those few games where your best build is also your favorite. all that said, the cost for this game is absurdly high, so i recommend just buying a cdkey somewhere online

Overall, it is sad that potentially a pretty decent game became almost like a chore most of the time. If the game had better design choices, even little tweaks here and there, I could see this game like a good souls-like. 5.5/10

What keeps Nioh from reaching the hights of the game it so clearly wants to emulate (Dark Souls) is its strict adherence to strange mechanics from DS that don't carry over to this game very well.  While the games combat system (involving 3 main stances that drastically change how each and every weapon handles) is pretty unique and quite rewarding to master, this game is so needlessly covered in endless game-design word-salad that I don't feel it's worth it.  Inclusions such as bafflingly steep enemy damage (many enemies will just one-shot you with attacks that have little to no telegraph), EVERY ITEM being strictly limited (and, for the most part, one time use), and the broken Mission system that essentially allows the player to soft-lock the game at any time by picking a mission that's too hard and not being able to leave, make many sections of this game a chore.  To note, Yes, you CAN leave a mission in this game, but it is tied to a limited resource that you CANNOT get more of within a level.  This game isnât Dark Souls hard, it's just unfair.  I have not finished Nioh, and I donât plan on doing so as this game becomes progressively less interesting as it requires me to repeat missions for better loot so I can even have a chance at completing the main story areas.  I can only really recommend this if you've played EVERY Fromsoftware action RPG and REALLY need more of that souls-like sweetness, and even then, just play Jedi Fallen order.
Also, shout out to Gamers Heroes, his guides on kodama locations saved me a lot of time in running around the map trying to find the last pesky one.
Though I must admit, I aam wholly looking forward to getting my hands on Nioh 2.
love this game
It's very similar to DS but unique nevertheless. Any DS fan should play this.

Best description for this game would be GaidenSouls. Nicely fills the void of not having a SoulsBorne game to play. It is unique enough that it's not a complete rip off of the SoulsBorne formula and in fact expands on the combat system magnificently, with a little flavor of Tenchu. It's not just about RB/RT etc, and the stance mechanic is very rewarding once you find your favorite weapon(s) and really learn it's moveset. The variation of builds is almost endless and players are not limited by excessive (or oppressive) RNG. THE ONLY downside to this game is that it is arranged into "Missions", instead of an open seamless world like Dark Souls or Bloodborne, and there is no Invasion mechanic. Instead, players can summon Revenants, AI controlled "Invader" shades of dead players, including their skills and gear; killing them actually rewards you with the equipment they are wearing! 9/10

Very intruiging and engaging game! The difficulty is there, however, it is not lasily cheap where luck becomes a big factor. The level design is great and encourages exploration, not sticking to a linear path. The loot system is similar to Diablo III or the Borderlands series. For the comparison to the Soulsborne series, it is relatively similar. There are MANY differences which set this game out from the others. The combat is much more fluid and fast paced. Combos are a big part of battles and must be utilized safely and correctly to effectively deal with enemies. The loot system is vastly different with several rarities for items. Overall a very fun game, it even comes with all DLC in this edition!

The coop is great and is the main thing that's held my interest. Although there's a few issues with it as well.  The biggest one one is that most of the time it takes a long time to find a match.  It's not a lack of people playing coop either. When you finally get in one you can tell the person has been searching for a visitor for a long time (they are far from the shrine and lots of stuff is dead already).

Fantastic story.  Extremely responsive button control. (Play with a game pad personally for i find it easier then keyboard)  High repetition though, constant gear cycles and forging can be a bit pointless for the most part.  Overall solid game.

edit: finally got to way of the nioh got level 300 gear and all the graces and all that stuff, I love this game, if you are tired of the slow and simple combat of a souls game you might like this one!

With all that in mind, I still wanted to explore more of the game, since the combat has a nice rhythm to it and I was curious about seeing more of the bosses. The art direction there is really great, everything looks decent for a 2017 game, and the sound effects and ambiance were solid. The rhythm of combat feels pretty good once you start to get a handle on the different weapons, stances, defensive movements, and how those square against the regular enemy types and mini-bosses, but for me that wasnât nearly enough to justify anymore time with Nioh. This game clearly needed me to âgit gudâ to experience it properly, but the glass ceiling of my own skill is just too low for that to happen.

TL;DR: Love it. Doesn't waste my time with aimless wandering, has plenty of secrets that are reasonably discoverable (i.e. none of this 'indistinguishable hidden walls' bullcrap that require you to hit EVERY wall just to make sure you didn't miss anything - Nioh's hidden walls have a little more ... personality to them), great combat, love the inventory system, not the best PC controls porting (it still shows X-box buttons, so you have to do a mental mapping to the actual keyboard key, but I found stance-switching with specific hotkeys a hell of a lot more fluid on KBM than a Controller), but once you get the hang of it, its just an absolute blast to play. Can't recommend this game enough to someone who wants a more casual-friendly Souls-like that won't hesitate to challenge you and give you opportunities to excel.

I don't have a lot to say here. The game has a lot of good things going for it. Combat is fast, responsive and satisfying. Armor and weapons are just as unique as in Dark Souls, especially due to the fact that the player can wield these weapons in different stances. I'm indifferent to the Ki mechanic, I guess to me it just seems kind of unnecessary. Level design is smart. Enemies are fun to fight, aside from the lack of variety. Most bosses are good fights, if not somewhat easy. Unfortunately, what ruined this game for me is the copy+pasted enemies, bosses and levels. Like I said before, all three of those things are good in their own right, but when they are shoved down the player's throat over and over again, it's hard not to get sick of it. I might like a steak once a week, but not for every meal. Farming revenants is also an incredibly annoying way to aquire new gear. Revenant fights are the same every singe time, no matter what weapon they are using, so of course it's going to get boring after the first few fights. I understand the implementation of a rarity based loot system is due to the fact that there are only 7 weapon types in the game, but I believe it could have been executed in a better way, without having the game become a total grind-fest. I would recommend getting the game on sale, but don't go into this game expecting it to be of the same caliber as FromSoftware.

fresh from nioh 2 coming back to this game...it felt wrong and right. it felt right because going from game to game you have a better understanding of the mechanics, how the game feels, stances, ki etc...the wrong would be because this game is slightly more unbalanced but i also found it a lot less complicated then the second game when it came to getting everything down while playing. the story again, was interesting but also kinda forgettable. i did like this story and thought it was a bit easier to follow then the 2nd games. this game still kicks your ass as much as the 2nd one but if you play them back to back or in a near time span, it will more then likely benefit you. got this game for $14 and enjoyed the time with it that i got. it's hard to say if i believe these games are harder then fromsoft's but if anything they are on equal level with fromsoft's endgames. recommend this to those who want a serious challenge and/or are into souls games!

Nioh is a pretty different Souls-like, with an advanced stamina management and dynamic combat postures. The Co-op system is very refreshing for the genre. Additionally, the combo variety with stances makes aggressive play pretty engaging and interesting (rather than just timing a massive i-frame every few hits right against the boss's leg). I feel like all the weapon classes were given love in terms of balance. The game has a lot of goofy cute guardian spirits, including neon blue and pink doggies.
Dont buy it if you are prone to throwing controllers. Do buy it if you want something better than Dark Souls.
As a mandatory note on performance, it runs fine at 60 fps maxed out (except blur, cause that effect is just ugly)

The game gradually makes me feel so frustrated due to the unfair difficulty.  Many creeps spawned in cluster, mini bosses spawned in cluster, even in some mission you have to deal with 2 bosses at the same time. Most of the boss fights take place in such a narrow area, it's very common to stuck in some decorations when dodging and got hit in the face. Bosses are also been overused, old bosses will be used as mini bosses in the next map not just once but multiple times. The creeps are the same, it just have a few typical enemies for some maps, the game just mix them together to make new level. I don't know if the devs are lazy or something. The last thing will be the key bindings, it's true that the key bindings is the real boss of this game. I play this game with mouse and keyboard but it just display controller key icon when interact with something. I wonder if anyone can play this game with the default key bindings, I've tried and it is a true nightmare. That's why I have to use another settings for mouse and keyboard in the forum, and I have to get used to it from the beginning. It was a very tough time for me to get used to the game control.

Out of all the many Souls-like that exist out there, most fail to really capture the quality of From Software. Out of all the many Souls-like, Nioh is the exception! The presentation, level design, boss design, class builds, all shine with the same familiar quality any Dark Souls player would expect, but what's really exceptional about Nioh is that it doesn't just dwell on this successful imitation, it goes all out innovating too. Weapon stances, combos, ki, yokai realm, special spirit modes, it adds so much over the basic framework of a "Souls-like" it makes itself both instantly familiar but also unique. A must play if you're a fan of the genre!

There were many moments of cursing and pounding my fist into the table out of frustration due to what I perceived as outrageous defeats. My final point - I didn't master the game crafting system or fully grasp the set bonuses. Lots of keywords and bonuses that were hard to understand or navigate through especially using a keyboard/mouse setup. If your gonna make a dark souls clone then you gotta 1. do it right and 2. bring something new to the formula that you can't get in From's games. Nioh does both of these beautifully. It wears it's soulsborne influence on it's sleeve and nails everything that makes those games to beloved. Level design, difficulty scaling and player control are all top notch and feel right out of a From title- however Nioh isn't content to just make a feudal japan flavored souls game. It introduces an interesting mission based structure that allows the devs to remix all levels upon completion with interesting new challenges and side missions, and the H/M/L stance system allows you to have a wide variety of combat options regardless of the weapon you decide to invest skill points in. Overall a fantastic game that has skyrocketed it's sequel to one of my most anticipated titles of 2020
