i hate myself when i play this game, but yet like nicotine I'm addicted in the worst ways possible. The only buzz I get from the metaphorical hit from the vape of dead by daylight is the moaning from leon s. kennedy.

For 4 years the Devs have played the "I'm the parent I know what is right" card when it comes to balance or altering the game. They never listen to the community until after they mess up and even then they fight tooth and nail to not change what they broke or revert changes because they refuse to acknowledge their incompetence or ability to do things properly.

That being said, this game is crazy fun. Don't let the saltiness of the community keep you from buying the game. Grab it, have fun with it, and ignore anyone who might give you a hard time ;) And don't fixate too much on the ranking process unless you're absurdly highly competitive for some reason (also fine - just try not to let it push you into spouts of anger!), and even then, recognize that there are jerks who play this game, like any other game, and have fun while you compete!

Dead by Daylight is not a game. It is a cosmic punishment sent by indifferent gods to remind humanity of its insignificance. Booting it up is like willingly inserting your face into a malfunctioning wood chipper. Nothing makes sense. Hitboxes defy physics. Perks do not function unless you chant in Latin. Killers phase through walls like demonic glitches. Survivors collapse into puddles of incompetence the moment a heartbeat sounds. Every match is a dissertation in disappointment, a Shakespearean tragedy written by drunken raccoons on fire. You don't play Dead by Daylight you endure it, like a prisoner endures solitary confinement, counting the cracks in the wall until madness becomes your only friend. Updates break more than they fix, a perpetual motion machine of failure. Pallets fly away into the sky. Generators burst into flames because a moth sneezed on them. Flashlights either stun the killer or open a black hole on the map, no in between. Queue times feel longer than the lifespan of stars. And the reward for surviving? More blood points so you can suffer again. Again. And again. This game has personally lowered my IQ. My dreams are skill checks now. My hands tremble when I hear the Entityâs noise. If Dante had known about Dead by Daylight, there would have been a Tenth Circle of Hell and THIS would be the only thing playing. I would rather be force-fed glass by a rabid moose than ever install this corrupt, festering, soul-devouring, sadness-engine ever again. Dead by Daylight isnât a horror game. Itâs a warning. A cursed artifact. It is a SCREAM into the VOID and the VOID screams back.

I am a 69 year old grandfather, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am the guardian to my grandson, who is now 15. My grandson recently downloaded Dead by Daylight and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my grandson, as he is always out with his friends and I was busy having parish zoom call meetings. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Grandson for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my grandson since I'm no longer chairman of the parish council. This game has ever since brought my grandson and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my grandson many happy memories.
If you are new and thinking of buying this game, don't do it for your own good and your nerves.

I walk alone in a forest until I see a generator. I don't know why or how but I start repairing it. My heart beat pounds within my chest. A strange man appears from the shadows wearing a mask and hits me with something sharp. I yell out in pain and run for my life. I vault windows and drop pallets on my relentless pursuer. But despite my best efforts I end up cornered. I can hear fast approaching footsteps, they almost sound excited with anticipation. With nowhere left to go I jump into a locker. The man passes me by and I think I'm safe, but then manic eyes gaze into my own through a slit in the locker. I try to move, I try to scream, but it all happens in slow motion, and the next thing I know I'm being carried and thrown on a hook. I scream until someone rescues me and I run with them. But then the manic sadist reappears and I get separated from my rescuer. The pursuer follows me, getting closer as I run out of breathe, almost exhausted. I hear the sound of metal hitting concrete as I throw the last of my strength into vaulting a window. I gaze behind me, thinking my pursuer will surely follow, but the sadist just watches me as I stagger between two tall posts and escape into the night.

This game has truly been a very memorable journey, there is definitely a good, a bad, and an ugly to this game. I personally feel Dead by Daylight is a must play for horror fans or people who just want a good scare every now and then or be the people who want to scare others!. Dead by Daylight is without a doubt not a perfect game as most aren't, but I believe every penny I spent on this game was well worth it. I wouldn't even mind paying full price. Within Dead by Daylight you'll come across so many different types of people while playing; people who care for each other even if they are just strangers just trying to accomplish the same goal survive, people who are complete â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ that will make you feel like an idiot for almost no reason, people that are poor sports ETC disconnecting from the game if something doesn't go their way or feel something that the killer did was not fair (which sometimes can be understood if you too see it as a good reason). People who you can relate with, have a good laugh and even become lifelong best friends, you will also come across people who you wonder are even on the same planet as you in terms of how they appear on profile/act in game. If you plan on buying this I'd suggest making sure that you are a good sport; don't just follow one survivor at a time until they die (tunneling), don't drop pallets onto other survivors that didn't do anything wrong (exception for playing with friends wanting to see them die and if they agree to trying to fight you off during the match along with the killer trying to kill your team), don't call people meaningless stupid names after the match is done its just unnecessary negative energy that nobody deserves/needs. I feel this game might help you understand a little bit more about yourself in terms of what kind of perks you like to use, how you work with others, how you kill survivors, what killers you like, what survivors you like. You might even discover if you really do have anger issues or are a poor sport after all Â¯\_(ã)_/Â¯. This game has A LOT of replayability in my opinion with months and months of grinding blood points to put into your favorite killers/survivors to unlock new perks even leveling them to prestige three having a full bloody outfit for them for every character in the game killer/survivor, collecting iridescent shards to unlock new cosmetics for the characters you enjoy playing as. This game might even be seen as therapeutic to some people such as myself, some people say they cant start their day off right without coffee for me its I cant start my day off right without killing people or fighting off a bloodcrazed killer coming for me. If you deal with a lot of stress killing survivors or pallet slamming a killer might make you feel better or even saving a teammate in the heat of combat might make you feel better. You can most certainly make friends in this game and forge friendships after just hours of gameplay!. If you already have close friends that enjoy horror and video games I'd highly recommend you invite them to play with you as it could be a great bonding experience. If you like horror memes this game has TONS of high quality memes in stock just waiting for you to see. In Dead by Daylight you will lose some and win some that's just how it is on this â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ of an Earth. This concludes my TEDtalk. Have a nice day â¤â¤â¤

"I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 16. My son recently started Dead By Daylight and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories."

So all in all, the game CAN be fun, if it works and you aren't stuck with toxic people. But honestly, the cons outweigh the pros. For the price of the game and DLC, I'd assume they have more than enough money and time to fix these issues but they clearly have different priorities. There are other issues with this game, like the ranking system being messed up and practically useless, but I feel what I've said is more than enough.  It's sad to see a game like this end up on a track this bad.

In conclusion, my personal experience and observations have left me disillusioned with BHVR's management and the state of the game. It's a far cry from what it used to be, and I can't in good conscience recommend it to anyone at this point.

If your idea of fun is playing a game of tag with someone, then turning around to flip them off everytime they lunge for you and miss, we don't want you. You're a bully, and everyone would be better off without your company.

This makes the gaming experience extremely unsatisfactory. You feel like you're left in the dark after each match, with the disappointing sensation that you never win. You only "don't lose". And even then, you can still very clearly lose. What a sham.

To end this I would like to quote one of the developers who was asked the question "Do you have any ideas on how you are going to impove the killer experience?"  This was responded to with "Maybe try survivor for a bit, or play something else for like a week. Try civilization or something." This was literally a developer saying that they aren't going to fix the obvious balance issues that there game has. I hope that in the future this game will be fixed and will once again be a magnificent and unique horror game, but for now please avoid it for your own sake.

In all the years I have spent playing video games, I have never been more upset and disappointed at a development team than I am at BHVR. I have put almost 3,000 hours into this game playing both killer and survivor because it's actually fun, unique, and addicting. You can play a range of killers that all have unique powers and have their place in the game, or you can play as a survivor with some bomb ass cosmetics. Not to mention the licensing from popular classic horror movies and video games. There is no other game out there that can compete with Dead by Daylight.  However, with each new patch that is released, it has become apparent that the devs do not care about their community. They add killers whose powers are unbalanced, perks that are broken and unfun for both sides, and matchmaking has been in a state of misery making solo q survivor unbearable and killer boringly easy. Each patch is met with new cosmetics and random changes that no one asked for rather than addressing bugs that are game breaking. On top of this, the feedback they receive on their changes are completely ignored. What is the point of releasing a PTB and gathering feedback if none of it matters, and they're going to release the changes anyway? No one wanted graphical updates. No one enjoyed being forced to kick breakable walls to break infinites that have been reintroduced to maps. No one enjoys being hit from 10m away because of desync. No one wanted a new HUD. No one wanted new movement. It hurts to see a development team willingly kill their game because they simply don't care what their community has to say about it when their community is what is keeping the game alive. I have put almost 3,000 hours into this game because I love it, and now I regret ever buying it. Save yourself the trouble, and do not buy this game until the devs show they actually deserve the money you are about to give them.

The learning curve is pretty high. It's understandable to be frustrated at first or find it difficult. If you decide it isn't for you, there is no shame in that. You tried to enjoy the game, and time is valuable. It might be better for you to spend it somewhere else if you are not getting value from the game. However, if you still want to stick with it, I will say just continue playing. Experience will help greatly as you learn the maps and different perks.

The majority of your skill depends on your strategies, reflexes and looping/mind gaming. Although all of them can be affected by perks, your baseline skill is what will win trials. Early on, certain healing/aura/exhaustion perks will help as you get used to the game. No matter what you end up with at the start, try adapting so you can learn to use all>any>no perks, itâs silly and lots of fun. Perks cause play style variety that adds flavour otherwise itâs like playing a time management sim whilst being chased down by a scary monster. ðð

I am a 48 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently downloaded Dead by Daylight and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Overall DBD is fun and definitely worth a try, give it 20 hours and you'll start to understand the core gameplay as killer / survivor, but this game is very addictive and some people probably don't need that in their life :)
p.s. Game gets better when you play it with friends.

Other aspects of the game I enjoy are the collaboration Dead by Daylight had with Resident Evil. Leon, Jill, and the Nemesis are great additions to the game and I hope to see more collaborations with different games. The game anniversary items are also a nice addition to the game. The sacrificial cakes (anniversary offering that gives 105% more bloodpoints) give a significant amount of bloodpoints (game currency to upgrade characters). This really helps with people who just got the game, like me and my friends. We are able to level up our characters really fast and progress in the game a lot easier. The game is super fun and I totally recommend this to people who are looking for a game to play with friends competitively, casually, or even both! I also think that the DLC is worth it (although get it when it goes on sale or your friend has it on library share)! All the characters are really fun to play! + All characters are needed to complete all achievements.

Dead by Daylight is a wonderful game, just not for beginners. It is one of the worst multiplayer games to pick up and play due to the sheer amount of knowledge required just to get started, and the lack of a competent tutorial does NOT help. However, if one is willing to suffer for a few hundred hours to get to an average skill level, Dead by Daylight can be one of the most fun and in depth multiplayer games out there. The infinite techs and nuances surrounding each and every killer allow for thousands of hours of niche mechanical and strategic development that very few games can offer. After accruing nearly 2k hours across both Steam and Console, I often still find myself learning new things about the game, and even the killer that I specialize in, and have put hundreds of hours into mastering. Overall, Dead by Daylight is a great game for someone that is seeking a (VERY) challenging but rewarding experience.
Even though, i'm gonna keep playing it because at the end, i like it.

The premise and implementation of the game is great, and I understand that it's ridiculously hard to balance a game of this nature to where the majority of players are pleased. There's a reason why so many people have pumped hundreds, if not thousands, of hours into this game. The Devs are visible, they try to keep the community informed, and are always releasing new content, which is great, but I believe that more focus needs to be put into ensuring the core of the game is perfected first. If you're new, you're in for a rough ride, but it gets better, and much more enjoyable. There's alot of great aspects to the game, which makes it worth spending time in. You *will* get frustrated, you *will* have some absolutely horrible matches, but you "Join a Lobby" and take another stab at it. Overall, the good outweighs the bad in my opinion, and I trust the developers to keep chipping away at the monumental task that is balancing the game.
TLDR: It's good, just stay positive and don't let the negativity get to you, its just a game, have fun.

I have seen many different games fail because of the same reason: Developers not listening to their player base and being high and mighty with ideas that they created in a vacuum and thinking they 'know better' than their community. This is exactly what happened with Dawn of War III, The Culling, and Friday the 13th to name a few. The developers of those games made unwarranted and unasked for changes to their game and then proceeded to bite the bullet andkeep those changes even after they had received negative feedback from their community. All of those games were completely dead within 3 months of making those changes and sticking through with them. Because DBD has a much larger player base than those games it is more likely the players will significantly drop over an extended period of time. But this game could easily lose half its player base within 1 year if they keep doing this to their community. The game is bugged and the animations did not even need changes in the first place. I played a match where the match just ended when one person used the key to open hatch. Just instantly match end even though only one person went through the hatch. I am leaving a negative review to stop the trend of these terrible patches, even though this patch is still somewhat bearable. But BHVR needs negative feedback otherwise in 2 more bad patches this game could easily die off and I am trying to prevent that.

I, as a devoted fan of Dead by Daylight, have spent over 3000 hours in this game. Over this time, I have witnessed many changes, both positive and negative. The problem I've encountered is not only the developers' policy of dividing players based on region, but also, unfortunately, the rampant cheating that no one seems to be combating. Bhvr, in my opinion, treats some regions as first-class and others as second-class, and this is reflected not only in exclusive content but also, possibly, in different approaches to moderation in different regions. This logic is incomprehensible to me. Releasing exclusive content for specific regions creates an artificial division between players, undermines the sense of community unity, and generates dissatisfaction. Apparently, they have already earned enough money, and they no longer need it. And such a simple idea that it is necessary to unite people, not divide them, is apparently too difficult for Bhvr. Therefore, until their policy changes for the better, I am forced to stop spending any money on their projects, and I see no point in continuing to play them. It's not so much the skins themselves that matter, but rather the dismissive attitude from BHVR. Good luck to them with such decisions.

I liked the game so much in the beginning, but over the years realized that Bhvr doesn't take care of their game or older community as well as they should (even their newer players). Matchmaking is never balanced, rank doesn't matter, so then why place good survivors with inexperienced ones vs good killers or inexperienced killers? That doesn't make it very enjoyable. It makes it imbalanced and unfun for one or more parties. I play both killer and survivor and would love to play more, but what's the point? Releasing DLC to bandage problems the game has had for years is not a proper solution. They've been fixing maps to make them fair which is nice, but generator times/objectives are almost always survivor favored. Maps are generally survivor favored, I should know. I've seen the loops that are possible and not all infinites are gone yet, but they've said they're handling them - which they are, just not very fast. Like I said, releasing all these skins and DLC are not fixing the main issues. I just want the game to be fun again, but I don't see that happening anytime soon. I recommend taking breaks from the game when you know it's not going so well. Their servers need improvement and their matchmaking is terrible. I call it the Lobby Simulator for a reason.

Essentially, Dead by Daylight is an awful experience due to an incompetent dev that makes horrible changes, a nonfunctional matchmaking system, and a base structure that lacks the substance to make itself versatile enough. This is all while being topped off with a community that craves self-fulfillment in their life by forcing a fun co-op game with friends to turn into a competitive esport, simultaneously lashing out at the players around them. Will I keep playing this game? Probably. It's fun with friends (albeit that isn't a genuine positive in my eyes, everything is fun with friends). It doesn't change the fact that this is a game where those who feel insecure about their lives and desperately need reaffirmation that they're good at something come to spend thousands of hours and knowledge check everyone around them for fake accomplishment. This game was never intended to be as competitive as people make it out to be and it's led to the degradation of a game that had a lot more potential.

This Game is essentially Murder: The Hide and Seek Video Game. You have two sides in each match, survivors, and killers. One killer hunts down four survivors, and one killer has to do the job as such. They(The survivors) don't get any weapons and will have to escape using perks (skills, running faster for 3 seconds with a 40-60 second cooldown) or items like flashlights (blinds and stuns the killer so he can't see you run away for around 5 seconds or so.) They can also drop what are called 'pallets' onto killer players which are found in tight corners or open spaces to give more distance, as the killer has to spend time breaking it or going around to get to you again. However, they do have an advantage. The second that you run you leave little red 'scratch marks' on the ground that lead the killer to you. Most of the time when you are hit, you will be put into the wounded state, meaning you limp around while crying and drop blood, the killer can follow that blood directly to you, so the main job is to hide and not be found, as the longer you're chased the more disadvantages you'll have (Such as the killer attaining bloodlust, which makes him move way faster, on top of them already moving faster than you in the first place). It's not designed to be a fair 1v1 experience, it's designed to be a 4v1, and as such the killer is much stronger than a survivor and as such can easily beat them after a short time and put on a hook. If you get hung on a hook you have a certain amount of time to get off before the game kills you. Known as 'stages' each time you're on the hook you'll progress a stage, or if you're on too long. There's three stages. The first you can get out of the hook with ease, the second you'll have to mash spacebar constantly to avoid going into three, someone will have to rescue you before you die. It's a VERY fun game with a wide variety of options and ways to have fun. Don't be worried about the 'toxic community' as the only time the enemy team can even talk to you is post-match if you're killer, and as survivor only for the first few seconds before the match starts. During the game no contact can be made by or to either side, making the tension and teamwork a requirement. I heavily recommend this game if you have friends and plan to play survivor, or if you don't and want to be a killer. Being a survivor alone isn't that bad. People say that you'll get tunneled (The only survivor the killer hunts) and die, and while this is true, it doesn't matter at all. What tactics are employed by either side are a part of the game (Save the occasionally patched exploit.) In all, this is a very fun game for people who casually play games, or people who seriously play games. It doesn't matter how you enjoy games, there's a place here for you. If you're concerned about salty or toxic people just don't read the pre/post-game chat and you won't see problems. (Yes, tbagging can happen to you as killer but in that case just camp their hook and kill them, as killer you have the option to do whatever you please with them, and 'winning' is entirely subjective.) Ranks are the only real 'reason' to win the game, if that's what you really want in a hide-and-seek game go for it. Bloodpoints will be rewarded either way, and the amount is based on the 'feats' you pull off in-game, not your rank nor rank up materials. The game is wonky and absolutely unfair to survivors/killers at times, but both sides always have options of dealing with this, there's no reason to complain about it, it's just fun. Play it for fun, not for ranking. It's a Hide and Seek game for crying out loud, just enjoy yourself!

Having played the game for a while, through several updates, changes, reverts, the whole works, I can confidently recommend you NOT buy this game. The devs have consistently ignored player feedback, and have recently been making a lot of changes that made the game worse than it already was. This game requires you, currently, to be really good at the game to have consistent fun, since otherwise it's a sweatfest for no reason. Minecraft Dungeons is a very simplified take on the formula popularized by Diablo. Skill trees and direct stat customization are out, with most abilities and offensive options being determined by loot to a greater degree than similar games. For those new to the genre or those otherwise looking for a breezier version of it, particularly children, Minecraft Dungeons should be a solid experience, but more experienced players may be left in want by its lack of apparent depth.

I admit that I played this game previously on Playstation with a little couch co-op with my sons, but haven't played it for some time. When I saw it come to Steam I was excited since I play mostly PC. I have really been enamored with the game. I didn't buy into the Diablo 2 hype and I love action RPG's. I knew I liked this game already, but I didn't know how much I needed a game where I can pop in and out for a few minutes or hours at a time. I have so much fun finding new builds and enchanting new armor and weapons, playing with my son co-op is still easily the best thing. It's so easy to join friends games so I applaud them there. The ability to toggle difficulty is great too when you are playing with people or kids who need it to feel a little bit more epic and not as much dying. The difficulty is definitely there though if you are trying to get the highest level artifacts and weapons/ armor. I really enjoy the game and I hope to continue playing it here on PC for quite some time!

I want to say this game is good, I really do, I love playing it, and I love being in the game racing. But I feel like this game could be a LOT better with next to no effort from the development team. They could fix the unbalanced cars and instantly make the game 100x more fun to play online. They could remove cheated leaderboard scores & make getting the highest score mean something. They could actually add unique cars to the region, or listen to their damn community, but they won't. This feels like a "safe profit" game. A game manhandled by some execs into losing its soul just so it could be an easy game to profit from. It feels corporate, its not the same horizon you had as a child/teen on your xbox 360, and its not the same game as the previous title. Its a soulless husk of a game within a series that was at one point the greatest open world racing experience. I'm still going to play it, its one of the only open-world racing games & I dont exactly have a choice to fill that niche. I want this game to be the best it can be, but it really feels like i've joined just as the ship was going down. Good Graphics wont save a game with an awful experience, and this has been a champion of awful experiences lately.

Well done to the developers of this game.

Dead Cells rewards us with its flexibility that few games have. Each sequence is easily digested through magnificently detailed and dynamic levels that instill a sense of discovery and familiarity. It pushes you to push the limits of your abilities and crushes you without mercy when you feel too comfortable. There are layers of strategy and tactics not only in the immediate choices you make, but also in the more global meta of the game that you understand through your trials. Dead Cells is a triumphant union of instinct, foresight, fun and failure.
